items.editorNote: Arm Holdings, without manufacturing chips, dominates global computing by licensing its chip designs to power 99% of smartphones and over 300 billion chips worldwide.
keyPoints: Founded in 1990 as a spinoff from Acorn Computers, Arm started with only 12 engineers and £1.5 million funding.
Arm pioneered a licensing model charging upfront fees plus royalties per chip, avoiding costly chip fabrication.
The 1993 deal with Texas Instruments to supply Nokia phones validated Arm’s IP licensing and fueled global adoption.
Arm’s RISC architecture emphasizes power efficiency, enabling its designs to be used in devices from smartphones to electric cars.

readOriginal.reason: The original article contains detailed historical context on Arm’s founding, founder Robin Saxby’s strategic decisions, and early partnership specifics not fully captured in the summary.
readOriginal.whoShouldRead: Technology strategists and semiconductor industry analysts interested in Arm’s business model evolution and historical impact.
